Mobility Accelerates Learning: Convergence Analysis on Hierarchical Federated Learning in Vehicular Networks

Tan Chen, Jintao Yan, Yuxuan Sun,Â , Sheng Zhou,Â ,

Abstract

Hierarchical federated learning (HFL) enables distributed training of models across multiple devices with the help of several edge servers and a cloud edge server in a privacy-preserving manner. In this paper, we consider HFL with highly mobile devices, mainly targeting at vehicular networks. Through convergence analysis, we show that mobility influences the convergence speed by both fusing the edge data and shuffling the edge models. While mobility is usually considered as a challenge from the perspective of communication, we prove that it increases the convergence speed of HFL with edge-level heterogeneous data, since more diverse data can be incorporated. Furthermore, we demonstrate that a higher speed leads to faster convergence, since it accelerates the fusion of data. Simulation results show that mobility increases the model accuracy of HFL by up to 15.1% when training a convolutional neural network on the CIFAR-10 dataset.

Index Terms:
Hierarchical federated learning, mobility, convergence analysis, heterogeneous data

I Introduction

The advent of 5G has revolutionized intelligent vehicles, enabling them to generate and share vast amounts of data through vehicle-to-everything (V2X) services[1]. In this context, machine learning (ML) has become an essential tool to efficiently exploit patterns of data while adapting to the dynamics of the mobile environment[2, 3, 4]. Conventional ML solutions rely on offloading the data collected by mobile devices to the cloud server. Such centralized solutions, however, encounter challenges of limited communication resources and privacy concerns in vehicular networks [5, 6, 7]. Federated learning (FL), where multiple devices cooperatively train a model by updating the model parameters with their local data and sharing the gradients through a parameter server, emerges as a privacy-preserving alternative, [1, 8]. FL has great potentials in various vehicular network scenarios, such as edge caching[9], resource allocation[10], and radio-based localization[11].

Nevertheless, FL faces challenges when applied to vehicular networks. Traditionally, the parameter server of FL is located on a remote cloud. However, the communication links between the cloud server and vehicles leads to large communication delays and dropout rate[12], resulting in a long training time[13]. Training tasks such as edge caching and channel estimation are required to be trained up-to-date based on the changing data generated by the dynamic environment, and the timeliness of these tasks can not be guaranteed by the cloud-based FL. Federated edge learning (FEEL), where an edge server acts as the parameter server, has a lower communication delay to vehicles[14, 15]. However, the edge server generally covers a small area, and the density of vehicles is low. As a result, the number of participating vehicles is often too small to make the model converge[1]. To balance the trade-off between training delay and coverage range, hierarchical federated learning (HFL) has been proposed[17, 16], which trains a global model at a central cloud server in a federated manner with the help of edge servers. The wide coverage of the cloud server ensures sufficient participating vehicles, while the edge servers are mediators for model aggregation, which help decrease the total training time.

In this work, we consider HFL in vehicular networks (see Fig. 1 for an illustration). The performance of HFL in vehicular networks is mainly affected by two factors. Firstly, different vehicles have diverse routes and may collect data with diverse statistics, e.g., different classes, resulting in data heterogeneity (or, non-i.i.d. data)[18, 8]. Heterogeneous data causes the local objective function to diverge from the global objective function, thereby degrading the learning performance[19, 20]. Many research efforts have been devoted to the problem of heterogeneous data in FL and HFL, but few in the context of vehicular networks. Secondly, unlike traditional HFL where the devices are fixed, the mobility of vehicles dynamically changes the network topology. The impact of mobility in HFL is examined in [21], but the authors claim that mobility deteriorates the training performance by decreasing the number of vehicles that successfully upload their models.

We have a different perspective on the impact of mobility on HFL. On the one hand, the movements of vehicles cause frequent cell handovers and channel variations, which makes the uploading of models from the vehicles to the edge servers more difficult. Vehicles may frequently receive the edge model from one edge server, while uploading its local model to another. This phenomenon is called shuffling the edge models. On the other hand, mobility promotes mixing of heterogeneous data, because vehicles can act as â€˜data mulesâ€™[22], which potentially improve the learning performance. This is called fusing the edge data.

Therefore, in this work, we investigate the effect of mobility on the performance of HFL. The main contributions of our work can be summarized as follows.

  • â€¢

    We analyze the upper bound of the loss function of general HFL tasks w.r.t. heterogeneous data and general mobility models, showing how mobility influences the bound.

  • â€¢

    We further analyze the performance of HFL for classification tasks with Markov mobility of vehicles. Three typical initial label distributions are discussed and theoretical results demonstrate that mobility improves the performance of HFL with edge-level label imbalance. Specially, when the edge servers form a ring topology, a higher vehicle speed leads to faster convergence.

  • â€¢

    Through simulations we show that mobility indeed enhances the convergence speed and accuracy of HFL with edge-level label imbalance. Furthermore, the potential of mobility to reduce resource consumption is studied.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces the related work. Section III describes the system model, characterizes the learning task, and presents the training algorithm. In Section IV, convergence analysis of the system is conducted, showing the impact of mobility on HFL with heterogeneous data. Section V presents simulation results and discussions. Finally, Section VI concludes the work.

II Related Work

The issue of heterogeneous data has gained attention ever since the inception of FL. In [8], it is highlighted that non-i.i.d. data across devices is a natural occurrence in FL. To date, numerous efforts have been made to address this problem, which can be broadly categorized into three types: data-based, algorithm-based, and framework-based[23, 24]. Data-based methods aim to balance data among different devices by sharing a small portion of global data[25] or generating augmented samples[26]. Algorithm-based methods focus on designing specific aggregation[27, 28] or optimization strategies[29]. Framework-based methods employ new paradigms to model the data heterogeneity of devices, such as multi-task learning[30], personalized learning[31], and clustering[32, 33]. Nonetheless, these studies treat data heterogeneity as a generic phenomenon[34], and most of them examine the performance of their algorithms by simulations without much analysis on the convergence bound of FL.

The authors of [35] classify data heterogeneity into four specific types: feature distribution skew, label distribution skew, concept shift between features and labels, and quantity skew. Among them, label distribution skew, also known as class imbalance, is more prevalent in realistic scenarios. Consequently, most subsequent researches focus on this aspect.

Simulations have demonstrated that imbalanced data negatively impacts the training performance[20]. A mitigation strategy is then proposed, which measures the class imbalance by the ratio between the number of samples in the majority class and the minority class, and adds the ratio loss to the training loss. In [36], devices are categorized into uniform and biased groups based on their data distributions. Mediators are then introduced to manage the training and balance biased devices according to the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence of their data distributions. The authors of [34] adjust the cross-entropy loss based on the occurrence of each class to train a more balanced local model. The final classifier layer of the neural network, typically a softmax layer, is modified in [36, 37]. A scaling factor is introduced into the softmax function to accommodate missing classes in [36], while the i.i.d. raw features are employed to calibrate the trained model [37]. The accuracy decrease in FL with non-i.i.d. data is attributed to weight divergence in [25], where earth moverâ€™s distance (EMD) is introduced as a measure to quantitatively assess weight divergence. Although the class imbalance problem is effectively addressed in these work, vehicular network scenarios are not considered, where the mobility of vehicles impact the training performance.

In the context of vehicular networks, to balance the training time and the number of participating vehicles, HFL structure is considered, where vehicles cooperatively train a global model with the help of the cloud and edge servers. Several work attempt to reduce the degree of heterogeneity of HFL by shaping the data distribution at the edge. The user-edge association problem is often considered, which involves allocating users that fall under the coverage of multiple edge servers. By minimizing the KL divergence among the data distribution of each edge server, a user-edge association method is adopted in [38], reducing the total number of communication rounds during training. The authors of [39] model the optimal user-edge association problem by minimizing the weight divergence between the global and optimal models, which can be further converted to data distribution imbalance. As a result, the assignment problem is transformed into a distributed optimization problem. Despite the value of these work, they do not consider the change in data distribution when vehicles move.

The impact of mobility in HFL is examined in [21]. The convergence speed of HFL in relation to mobility rate is analyzed, showing that mobility decreases the convergence speed of HFL, and an algorithm is then proposed to mitigate the impact of mobility by adopting cosine similarity as the aggregating weights. However, the authors ignore vehicles that cross the coverage of edge servers (crossing vehicles) when edge servers aggregate models of vehicles. In contrast, we think the data on the crossing vehicles is important as they help mix diverse data, so these vehicles should also be considered.

Theoretical analysis of FL with heterogeneous data has been conducted by several work. The authors of [40, 41] measure non-i.i.d. by the upper bound of gradient divergence and the difference between the optimal values of the local and global loss functions, respectively. The corresponding convergence bounds with respect to the non-i.i.d. metrics are then derived. Subsequent work [16, 21, 42, 43, 44, 45] further analyze the convergence bound for HFL with heterogeneous data. These work does not consider the scenario of vehicular networks, so the impact of mobility is not examined.

The authors of [2] suggest that mobility has two-fold impacts on data-heterogeneous FL. On the one hand, it brings uncertainties to the network topology, which may decrease the number of vehicles that successfully upload the model or deteriorate the quality of the model. On the other hand, it facilitates data fusion which potentially accelerates the convergence speed of training. Simulations show that mobility increases training accuracy of the edge-based FL. Following this work, we further exploit the impact of mobility in the scenario of data-heterogeneous HFL.

III HFL in Vehicular Networks

We consider HFL in vehicular networks. A central cloud server equipped with a macro base station controls several edge servers, which can represent base stations or roadside units. Each edge server is static, and covers a limited area of streets. The vehicles move on the streets and cross the coverage of an edge server occasionally. We assume that the cloud server has a large enough coverage, so all the vehicles are always within its coverage. Therefore, the cloud and edge servers, and the vehicles together form a closed system without input and output flows. We denote the central cloud as C, and assume that there are Nğ‘N edge servers and Mğ‘€M mobile vehicles. In practice, Mğ‘€M is much larger than Nğ‘N. The vehicles in the system cooperatively train a model with the help of the cloud and edge servers.

III-A Mobility-aware Hierarchical Federated Averaging

We follow the HFL framework in [16, 17] while further incorporating the mobility of vehicles. We call the stochastic gradient descent (SGD) process on a batch of samples at each vehicle as a local update. We maintain an iteration enumerator Ï„ğœ\tau, which records the number of local updates each vehicle has carried out in total. A synchronized system is considered, so Ï„ğœ\tau is tracked by all the vehicles. We denote the models of the mğ‘šm-th vehicle, the nğ‘›n-th edge server, and the cloud server at iteration Ï„ğœ\tau as ğ’˜m(Ï„),ğ’˜e,n(Ï„),ğ’˜(Ï„)superscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘šğœsuperscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘’ğ‘›ğœsuperscriptğ’˜ğœ\boldsymbol{w}_{m}^{\left(\tau\right)},\boldsymbol{w}_{e,n}^{\left(\tau\right)},\boldsymbol{w}^{\left(\tau\right)}, respectively.

III-B Data Distribution

The performance of HFL is affected by the data heterogeneity during training, which is mainly related to the initial data distribution and the mobility of vehicles. We consider three typical sampling cases of initial data distributions:

(1) i.i.d. The data patterns are homogeneous for all vehicles, and each vehicle owns a dataset of the same distribution.

(2) edge non-i.i.d. The training tasks have spatial dependence, such as trajectory forecasting and beam selection, where the data patterns depend on the location of vehicles. In this case, the data distributions are non-i.i.d. across edges, but i.i.d. among the vehicles within the same edge server.

(3) local non-i.i.d. The data patterns are heterogeneous for different vehicles. In this case, vehicles own datasets of different distributions. If the number of vehicles is large enough, the dataset of each edge server (denoted by the union of the datasets of all the vehicles within its coverage) is assumed to be i.i.d. (edge i.i.d.), since the data of vehicles is sufficiently mixed up; otherwise local non-i.i.d. leads to edge non-i.i.d..

III-C Mobility Model

Since the edge server that each vehicle belongs to at the time of edge aggregation is needed, the mobility of vehicles is modeled by a discrete Markov chain. The observation interval of the Markov chain is equal to the interval between two consecutive edge aggregations. The states of the Markov chain represent the relationship between the edge server and the vehicle, with a state space size Nğ‘N. Denote the transition probability matrix by ğ‘·âˆˆâ„›NÃ—Nğ‘·superscriptâ„›ğ‘ğ‘\boldsymbol{P}\in\mathcal{R}^{N\times N}, where the iğ‘–i-th row and jğ‘—j-th column element ğ‘·iâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘·ğ‘–ğ‘—\boldsymbol{P}_{ij} represents the probability of a vehicle that stays within the iğ‘–i-th edge server at the last epoch and moves to the coverage of the jğ‘—j-th edge server at the current epoch.

IV Convergence Analysis

In this section, the upper bound on the loss function of the Mob-HierFAVG algorithm for general tasks and classification tasks are derived. The impact of mobility is then discussed based on the bounds.

IV-A Convergence of HFL in static and mobile scenarios

The definition indicates that the cloud-local gradient difference is not time-varying, while the cloud-edge and edge-local gradient differences are. This is because the whole datasets of vehicles remain the same during training, while the dataset of each edge server varies over time due to the mobility of vehicles. Therefore, Î´msubscriptğ›¿ğ‘š\delta_{m} and Î”n(Ï„)superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘›ğœ\Delta_{n}^{(\tau)} represent the data heterogeneity impacted by the mobility of vehicles.

We then focus on bounding the CF difference in the static scenario and mobile scenario, respectively.

IV-A1 Static Scenario

In this scenario, we assume vehicles move in a small range and thus do not cross the coverage of edge servers during training. Then the edge gradient difference satisfies Î”(Ï„)=Î”superscriptÎ”ğœÎ”\Delta^{(\tau)}=\Delta.

In the static scenario, the CF difference has an upper bound

This is aligned with the conclusions in [21].

We now consider that vehicles have high mobility and may cross the coverage of edge servers.

Definition 1.

Fâ€‹(ğ’˜mob(T))âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ’˜âˆ—)ğ¹superscriptsubscriptğ’˜mobğ‘‡ğ¹superscriptğ’˜\displaystyle F\left(\boldsymbol{w}_{\text{mob}}^{\left(T\right)}\right)-F\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{*}\right) â‰¤1Tâ€‹(Î·â€‹Ï†âˆ’1Kâ€‹âˆ‘k=1KÏâ€‹Uk,mobÏ„lâ€‹Ï„eâ€‹Ïµ2)absent1ğ‘‡ğœ‚ğœ‘1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾ğœŒsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘˜mobsubscriptğœğ‘™subscriptğœğ‘’superscriptitalic-Ïµ2\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{T\left(\eta\varphi-\frac{1}{K}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\frac{\rho U_{k,\mathrm{mob}}}{\tau_{l}\tau_{e}\epsilon^{2}}\right)} (14)

Therefore, the effect of mobility with fixed Î·ğœ‚\eta, Tğ‘‡T and Uğ‘ˆU is determined by Î³â‰œ1Kâ€‹âˆ‘k=1KÎ³kâ‰œğ›¾1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜\gamma\triangleq\frac{1}{K}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\gamma_{k}. If Î³>0ğ›¾0\gamma>0, mobility accelerates the convergence speed of HFL; if Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0, mobility has no apparent influence on the convergence speed; if Î³<0ğ›¾0\gamma<0, mobility degrades the performance of HFL.

We also notice that Î³ksubscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜\gamma_{k} is composed of two parts, with the core elements Î”[0]âˆ’Î”[(kâˆ’1)â€‹Ï„e+j]superscriptÎ”delimited-[]0superscriptÎ”delimited-[]ğ‘˜1subscriptğœğ‘’ğ‘—\Delta^{[0]}-\Delta^{[(k\!-\!1)\tau_{e}+j]} and (Î´âˆ’Î”[0])â€‹Hâ€‹(Ï„l,Ï„e)ğ›¿superscriptÎ”delimited-[]0ğ»subscriptğœğ‘™subscriptğœğ‘’(\delta-\Delta^{[0]})H(\tau_{l},\tau_{e}), respectively. Here the first element expresses the evolution of the cloud-edge gradient difference, which is caused by the fusion of data on vehicles as they move across the coverage of edge servers. The second element emerges because some vehicles receive models from one edge server and upload their model updates to another edge server, which decreases the quality of models. Therefore, mobility influences the convergence bound of data-heterogeneous HFL in two ways, fusing the edge data and shuffling the edge models.

IV-B Convergence of HFL for classification tasks

To further analyze whether the mobility factor Î³ğ›¾\gamma is positive or negative, the magnitude relationship among Î´ğ›¿\delta, Î”[0]superscriptÎ”delimited-[]0\Delta^{[0]} and Î”[(kâˆ’1)â€‹Ï„e+j]superscriptÎ”delimited-[]ğ‘˜1subscriptğœğ‘’ğ‘—\Delta^{[(k\!-\!1)\tau_{e}+j]} should be figured out.

IV-B1 Mobility Factor for Classification Problem

Since Î´ğ›¿\delta, Î”[0]superscriptÎ”delimited-[]0\Delta^{[0]} and Î”[(kâˆ’1)â€‹Ï„e+j]superscriptÎ”delimited-[]ğ‘˜1subscriptğœğ‘’ğ‘—\Delta^{[(k\!-\!1)\tau_{e}+j]} are all related to the loss function, we further consider a classification task with Cğ¶C classes, which adopts the cross-entropy loss. Denote pâ€‹{y=c}ğ‘ğ‘¦ğ‘p\left\{y\!=\!c\right\} and pn[j]â€‹{y=c}superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›delimited-[]ğ‘—ğ‘¦ğ‘p_{n}^{[j]}\left\{y\!=\!c\right\} by the proportion of samples with label cğ‘c in the global dataset and the dataset of the nğ‘›n-th edge server at the jâ€‹Ï„lğ‘—subscriptğœğ‘™j\tau_{l}-th iteration, respectively. Assumption 2.

The global and edge loss functions for the classification task are denoted by

Fâ€‹(ğ’˜)ğ¹ğ’˜\displaystyle F\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right) =âˆ‘c=1Cpâ€‹{y=c}â€‹ğ”¼ğ’™|y=câ€‹[logâ¡giâ€‹(ğ’˜)],absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğ¶ğ‘ğ‘¦ğ‘subscriptğ”¼conditionalğ’™ğ‘¦ğ‘delimited-[]subscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ’˜\displaystyle=\sum\limits_{c=1}^{C}p\left\{y\!=\!c\right\}\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{x}|y\!=\!c}[\log g_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right)], (16)
Fe,n(jâ€‹Ï„l)â€‹(ğ’˜)superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘—subscriptğœğ‘™ğ’˜\displaystyle F_{e,n}^{(j\tau_{l})}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right) =âˆ‘c=1Cpn[j]â€‹{y=c}â€‹ğ”¼ğ’™|y=câ€‹[logâ¡giâ€‹(ğ’˜)],absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğ¶superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›delimited-[]ğ‘—ğ‘¦ğ‘subscriptğ”¼conditionalğ’™ğ‘¦ğ‘delimited-[]subscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ’˜\displaystyle=\sum\limits_{c=1}^{C}p_{n}^{[j]}\left\{y\!=\!c\right\}\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{x}|y\!=\!c}[\log g_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right)], (17)

Assumption 2 claims that the gradient difference can be expressed by the weighted sum of expectation of loss function over each class. In other words, the loss function, as well as its gradients, are determined by the class distribution.

Based on this assumption, the relationship between Î´ğ›¿\delta and Î”[0]superscriptÎ”delimited-[]0\Delta^{[0]} is derived as follows.

Proposition 2.

For classification tasks with the i.i.d. and edge non-i.i.d. initial distributions, Î´âˆ’Î”[0]=0ğ›¿superscriptÎ”delimited-[]00\delta-\Delta^{[0]}=0.

Proof.

For the i.i.d. case, the local and edge data distribution is identical to the global data distribution. According to Assumption 2, Î´=Î”[0]=0ğ›¿superscriptÎ”delimited-[]00\delta=\Delta^{[0]}=0. Similarly, for the edge non-i.i.d. case, the local data distribution is identical to the edge data distribution, so we obtain Î´=Î”[0]ğ›¿superscriptÎ”delimited-[]0\delta=\Delta^{[0]}. âˆ

Proposition 2 points out that the convergence bounds of the i.i.d. and edge i.i.d. cases are not impacted by shuffling the edge model.

To compare Î”[0]superscriptÎ”delimited-[]0\Delta^{[0]} with Î”[(kâˆ’1)â€‹Ï„e+j]superscriptÎ”delimited-[]ğ‘˜1subscriptğœğ‘’ğ‘—\Delta^{[(k\!-\!1)\tau_{e}+j]}, we consider deriving an upper bound of Î”[j]superscriptÎ”delimited-[]ğ‘—\Delta^{[j]}. Firstly, we have

From Theorem 3, the impact of mobility on data-heterogeneous HFL depends on the initial data distribution. Mobility has no apparent influence on HFL with i.i.d. data, decreases the convergence speed of HFL with local non-i.i.d. / edge i.i.d. data by shuffling the edge models, and accelerates the convergence of HFL with edge non-i.i.d. data by fusing the edge data.

IV-B2 Mobility Factor for Ring Topology

Next, we want to further dig into the edge non-i.i.d. case to study the improvement brought by mobility in more detail. The mobility factor in Eq. (31) connects the convergence bound of HFL with the eigenvalues of the transition probability matrix, but the relation between the eigenvalues and the speed of vehicles is not clear. In this part, a closed-form solution of eigenvalues is derived given specific topology and mobility model.

Assume edge servers are connected from head to tail to form a ring, and all edge servers are homogeneous in topology. For all the edge servers, the transition probabilities of vehicles is assumed to satisfy

(1) Vehicles within any edge server have the same sojourn probability pssubscriptğ‘ğ‘ p_{s},

(2) For each transient step, vehicles within each edge server can only move to the adjacent edge servers with equal probability.

Under these assumptions, the transition probability matrix is denoted by

ğ‘¸=[ps1âˆ’ps20â‹¯01âˆ’ps21âˆ’ps2ps1âˆ’ps2â‹¯0001âˆ’ps2psâ‹¯00â‹®â‹®â‹®â‹±â‹®â‹®000â‹¯ps1âˆ’ps21âˆ’ps200â‹¯1âˆ’ps2ps].ğ‘¸matrixsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ğ‘ 20â‹¯01subscriptğ‘ğ‘ 21subscriptğ‘ğ‘ 2subscriptğ‘ğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ğ‘ 2â‹¯0001subscriptğ‘ğ‘ 2subscriptğ‘ğ‘ â‹¯00â‹®â‹®â‹®â‹±â‹®â‹®000â‹¯subscriptğ‘ğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ğ‘ 21subscriptğ‘ğ‘ 200â‹¯1subscriptğ‘ğ‘ 2subscriptğ‘ğ‘ \displaystyle\boldsymbol{Q}=\begin{bmatrix}p_{s}&\frac{1-p_{s}}{2}&0&\cdots&0&\frac{1-p_{s}}{2}\\ \frac{1-p_{s}}{2}&p_{s}&\frac{1-p_{s}}{2}&\cdots&0&0\\ 0&\frac{1-p_{s}}{2}&p_{s}&\cdots&0&0\\ \vdots&\vdots&\vdots&\ddots&\vdots&\vdots\\ 0&0&0&\cdots&p_{s}&\frac{1-p_{s}}{2}\\ \frac{1-p_{s}}{2}&0&0&\cdots&\frac{1-p_{s}}{2}&p_{s}\end{bmatrix}. (32)

Then the closed-form solution of eigenvalues can be derived.

Lemma 2.

The transition probability matrix (32) is a circulant matrix with eigenvalues

Î»n=ps+(1âˆ’ps)â€‹cosâ¡(2â€‹nâ€‹Ï€N),n=0,1,â‹¯,Nâˆ’1.formulae-sequencesubscriptğœ†ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ğ‘ 2ğ‘›ğœ‹ğ‘ğ‘›01â‹¯ğ‘1\lambda_{n}=p_{s}+\left(1-p_{s}\right)\cos\left(\frac{2n\pi}{N}\right),\quad n=0,1,\cdots,N-1. (33)
Proof.

From (3.2) in [46], the eigenvalues of circulant matrices take the following form

Î»n=âˆ‘k=0Nâˆ’1ckâ€‹eâˆ’2â€‹Ï€â€‹iâ€‹kN,n=0,1,â‹¯,Nâˆ’1.formulae-sequencesubscriptğœ†ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ‘1subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘’2ğœ‹ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘›01â‹¯ğ‘1\lambda_{n}=\sum\limits_{k=0}^{N-1}c_{k}e^{\frac{-2\pi ik}{N}},n=0,1,\cdots,N-1. (34)

Here cksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜c_{k} denotes the kğ‘˜k-th component in the first row of the matrix. Taking Eq. (32) into Eq. (34), Eq. (33) is obtained. âˆ

Proposition 3.

For HFL with classification tasks, when the edge servers form a ring topology, the mobility factor in the edge non-i.i.d. case is expressed by

Î³k=Î·â€‹Gâ€‹Nâ€‹LÏ„eâ€‹âˆ‘j=1Ï„eâˆ’1jâ€‹[(1âˆ’ps)â€‹(1âˆ’cosâ¡(2â€‹Ï€/N))]kâ€‹Ï„e+j.subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜ğœ‚ğºğ‘ğ¿subscriptğœğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğœğ‘’1ğ‘—superscriptdelimited-[]1subscriptğ‘ğ‘ 12ğœ‹ğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğœğ‘’ğ‘—\displaystyle\gamma_{k}=\frac{\eta GNL}{\tau_{e}}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{\tau_{e}-1}j\big{[}(1-p_{s})\left(1-\cos\left(2\pi/N\right)\right)\big{]}^{k\tau_{e}+j}. (35)
Proof.

From (33) we have Î»âˆ—=ps+(1âˆ’ps)â€‹cosâ¡(2â€‹Ï€N)subscriptğœ†subscriptğ‘ğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ğ‘ 2ğœ‹ğ‘\lambda_{*}=p_{s}+\left(1-p_{s}\right)\cos\left(\frac{2\pi}{N}\right). Inserting it into (31), the proposition is proved. âˆ

From (35) we see that with a ring topology for the edge servers, the mobility factor is directly correlated to the sojourn probability of vehicles. Specifically, when vehicles move faster, their sojourn probability decreases, and the mobility factor Î³ğ›¾\gamma increases correspondingly, indicating the acceleration of the convergence speed of HFL.

V Simulation Results

In this section, we conduct simulations on HFL to show the influences of data heterogeneity and mobility and to verify our theoretical analysis.

V-A Simulation Settings

We consider a city road system on a square grid, where each side of the square is covered by an edge server, as shown in Fig. 5. There are N=4ğ‘4N=4 edge servers and a total of M=32ğ‘€32M=32 vehicles in the system, and each edge server covers 8 vehicles initially. The initial positions of vehicles are uniformly distributed. The Simulation of Urban MObility (SUMO)[47] platform with the Manhattan model is adopted to simulate the mobility of vehicles, which monitors real-world vehicle dynamics. The length of each side of the road is ağ‘a m, and vehicles travel on the road at a maximum speed of vğ‘£v m/s. Two main scenarios of the vehicle speed in simulations are considered:(1) the static scenario, where v=0ğ‘£0v=0; (2) the mobile scenario, where v=30ğ‘£30v=30 m/s. The interval between each edge aggregation is assumed to be 111 second. Since the edge servers follow the ring topology in our scenario, the mobility of vehicles is denoted by (32) with respect to the sojourn probability. As shown in Fig. 5, the average sojourn probability is negatively linearly correlated with the vehicle speed vğ‘£v with a high correlation coefficient. Therefore, we can approximately change the sojourn probability by changing the vehicle speed with a linear scaling factor.

HFL simulations are conducted on the CIFAR-10 dataset111https://www.cs.toronto.edu/Â kriz/cifar.html. We consider three initial data distributions mentioned above: i.i.d. case, local non-i.i.d. case, and edge non-i.i.d. case. To create heterogeneous data by uniformly distributing the classes to edge servers, we only choose data of 8 classes from the dataset, with 40000 training samples and 8000 testing samples in total. For the i.i.d. case, the 40000 training samples are uniformly divided into Mğ‘€M disjoint subsets, and allocated to vehicles so that each vehicle owns one subset. For the local non-i.i.d. case, all the data are sorted by labels and lğ‘™l classes are allocated to each vehicle (denoted by â€˜local niid(lğ‘™l)â€™ in the following), with all vehicles holding the same number of samples. For the edge non-i.i.d. case, the sorted data is first allocated to each edge server so that each edge server owns lğ‘™l classes of samples, and then the edge servers uniformly allocate their data to vehicles within their coverage area (denoted by â€˜edge niid(lğ‘™l)â€™ in the following).

We train a convolutional neural network (CNN) with a batch size of 20 using the following architecture: the first convolutional block consists of two 3Ã—3333\times 3 convolution layers with 32 channels, ReLU activation, followed by a 2Ã—2222\times 2 max pooling layer and 0.2 dropout; the second convolutional block contains two 3Ã—3333\times 3 convolution layers with 64 channels, ReLU activation, followed by a 2Ã—2222\times 2 max pooling layer and 0.3 dropout; a fully connected layer with 120 units and ReLU activation; and a final 10-unit softmax layer. The network takes an input of size 20Ã—3Ã—32Ã—32203323220\times 3\times 32\times 32 and produces an output of size 20Ã—10201020\times 10.

The learning rate is set to Î·=0.1ğœ‚0.1\eta=0.1. If not especially noted, the local period and edge period are set to Ï„l=6subscriptğœğ‘™6\tau_{l}=6 and Ï„e=10subscriptğœğ‘’10\tau_{e}=10, separately. The Mob-HierFAVG algorithm is run for up to K=600ğ¾600K=600 cloud epochs.

V-B Performance

V-B1 Impact of initial data distribution

The performance of HFL under several initial data distributions is shown in Fig 5. For the i.i.d. case, the maximum test accuracies of the static and mobile scenarios are approximately equal, which is consistent with (29). For the local non-i.i.d. case, the static accuracy is the same as the mobile accuracy, which is different from the local non-i.i.d. / edge i.i.d. case in (30). This is because the number of simulated vehicles is not large enough to produce edge i.i.d., and as long as edge non-i.i.d. happens in any cloud epoch, the effect of data fusion emerges, which offsets the negative effect of model shuffling. For the edge non-i.i.d. case, mobility obviously increases the performance. Specifically, when l=2ğ‘™2l=2, mobility improves the accuracy by 5.7% (74.9% to 80.6%); when l=1ğ‘™1l=1, mobility improves the accuracy by 15.1% (40.9% to 56.0%). These results reflect that if an edge server holds fewer classes, the accuracy of HFL decreases, while the accuracy improvement brought by mobility increases.

Furthermore, by comparing the results of local non-i.i.d. and edge non-i.i.d. cases when l=2ğ‘™2l=2, we find that the local non-i.i.d. case achieves a higher accuracy than the edge non-i.i.d. case in the static scenario, but reaches a similar accuracy with mobility. This phenomenon may originate from the equivalent aggregation period of heterogeneous data. In the local non-i.i.d. case, the data heterogeneity exists at the local level, so the edge aggregation sees a fusion of heterogeneous data, and thus the equivalent aggregation period is Ï„lsubscriptğœğ‘™\tau_{l} local updates. In the edge non-i.i.d. case, the data heterogeneity exists at the edge level, so only the cloud aggregation sees a fusion of heterogeneous data with the equivalent aggregation period of Ï„lâ€‹Ï„esubscriptğœğ‘™subscriptğœğ‘’\tau_{l}\tau_{e} local updates. As demonstrated in [48], a greater aggregation period results in worse training performance for heterogeneous data. However, when the vehicles start moving, data of different edge servers gradually mix up, and thus the equivalent aggregation period goes back to Ï„lsubscriptğœğ‘™\tau_{l}.

V-B2 Impact of vehicle speed

For the edge non-i.i.d. case, the impact of vehicle speed vğ‘£v on the convergence speed is further studied. As is shown in Fig. 6(a), the test accuracies of the scenarios with mobility, i.e., v>0ğ‘£0v>0, are obviously higher than the one achieved when v=0ğ‘£0v=0. Furthermore, the rounds to reach certain target accuracies are shown in Fig. 6(b), which demonstrates that with high accuracy requirements, mobility greatly reduces the training epochs, and thus saves resource utilization and power consumption. Also, Fig. 6(b) indicates that it takes nearly the same number of cloud epochs to reach the accuracy of 60% for all scenarios. Models of this accuracy contain basic features of the datasets without the information of class variety and generally can be achieved by pre-training. Actually, this situation usually happens in vehicular networks. For example, for the beam selection task, when the channel condition changes, the model needs to be fine-tuned, and the original model, which carries the basic features for beams, can be set as the pre-trained model.

Therefore, we further assume that the training is started from a pre-trained model with a test accuracy of 60%. With a pre-trained model, the training time is obviously decreased, as shown in Fig. 6(c) and 6(d). Besides, Fig. 6(d) illustrates that a higher speed generally results in faster convergence. In particular, it takes only 142 cloud epochs for the v=30ğ‘£30v=30 case to reach an accuracy of 75%, reduced by 65.5% compared with the v=0ğ‘£0v=0 case (412 epochs), and 39.8% compared with the v=1ğ‘£1v=1 case (236 epochs). These results are in line with the convergence analysis in Section IV.

On the other hand, the improvement brought by high mobility is limited. In our simulations, both the final accuracy and the convergence speed typically saturate beyond v=6ğ‘£6v=6 m/sğ‘šğ‘ m/s. Fig. 7 demonstrates that the evolving trends of 1-norm of the average probability difference of edges in v=6,15,30ğ‘£61530v=6,15,30 m/sğ‘šğ‘ m/s cases are similar. Therefore, the convergence performance saturates possibly because data from different edge servers is sufficiently mixed at v=6ğ‘£6v=6 m/sğ‘šğ‘ m/s, and no further gains can be achieved with even higher mobility. We also notice that the average probability difference does not monotonically decrease with time, but oscillates downward in a certain cycle. Besides, the theoretical analysis indicates that the average probability difference goes to zero after a long enough time, but during the simulation time, the value only decreases to around 0.4. These results may originate from the limited number of vehicles and training epochs.

V-B3 Impact of aggregation periods

Eq. (31) shows that the impact of mobility is correlated with not only the sojourn probability but also the aggregation periods and the number of vehicles. Further simulations are carried out for verification. Fig. 8(a) shows the test accuracy of the static and mobile scenarios for several values of Ï„esubscriptğœğ‘’\tau_{e}. In the static scenario, a small Ï„esubscriptğœğ‘’\tau_{e} results in faster convergence speed and higher accuracy; while in the mobile scenario, different values of Ï„esubscriptğœğ‘’\tau_{e} report similar convergence speed and test accuracy values. This finding indicates that mobility reduces the reliance on cloud aggregation, and thus saves communication resources.

The impact of local period Ï„lsubscriptğœğ‘™\tau_{l} is shown in Fig. 8(b). Although not explicitly expressed in the mobility factor, mobility slightly enhances the benefits of edge aggregation. For the Ï„l=12subscriptğœğ‘™12\tau_{l}=12 case, mobility improves the max test accuracy by 5.2% (73.5% to 78.7%); while for the Ï„l=3subscriptğœğ‘™3\tau_{l}=3 case, mobility improves the max test accuracy by 6.0% (76.4% to 82.4%).

From another perspective, if the local updates per cloud epoch Ï„lâ€‹Ï„esubscriptğœğ‘™subscriptğœğ‘’\tau_{l}\tau_{e} are fixed, we can learn the trade-off between the edge aggregation and cloud aggregation. Fig. 8(c) tells that mobility brings greater improvement when edge aggregation is more frequent.

V-B4 Impact of the number of vehicles

As demonstrated in Fig. 9(a), the number of edge servers does not influence the convergence in the static scenario, but if the vehicles have mobility, fewer edge servers contribute to higher test accuracy. However, this result is based on the assumption that the cloud server has a certain coverage. If the number of edge servers decreases, each edge server needs to cover a larger area, with a longer communication delay during the edge aggregation.

Fig. 9(b) demonstrates that more vehicles lead to higher test accuracy for both the static and mobile scenarios. This result basically matches the conclusion in FL: with more clients participating in the edge aggregation, the aggregated model is more stable, thus bringing a higher convergence speed. Besides, the improvement caused by adding vehicles is sharper for the mobile scenario, probably because with more vehicles, the probability difference of edges becomes smaller as the data of vehicles mix up.

VI conclusion

In this article, we have investigated the impact of mobility on data-heterogeneous HFL. The convergence analysis of HFL has been conducted, showing that mobility influences the performance of HFL by fusing the edge data and shuffling the edge models. Next, the mobility factors under three initial data distributions for classification tasks have been derived, which proves that mobility increases the convergence speed of HFL in the edge non-i.i.d. case. Furthermore, when the edge servers form a ring topology, a higher speed of vehicles lead to faster convergence of HFL. Simulations have been carried out on the CIFAR-10 dataset and the SUMO platform, demonstrating the benefits of mobility from multiple perspectives. Results have shown that mobility brings an increase in test accuracy by up to 15.1% in the edge non-i.i.d. case. Higher speed results in higher test accuracy, while the achieved accuracy saturates when the speed of vehicles exceeds 666 m/s. Moreover, mobility has also shown the potential for reducing training costs.

Lemma 5.

âˆ¥ğ’–n(Ï„)âˆ’ğ’—~(Ï„)âˆ¥â‰¤delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscriptğ’–ğ‘›ğœsuperscript~ğ’—ğœabsent\displaystyle\left\lVert{\boldsymbol{u}_{n}^{(\tau)}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}^{(\tau)}}\right\rVert\leq (78)
{(1+Î·â€‹Î²)â€‹âˆ¥ğ’–n(Ï„âˆ’1)âˆ’ğ’—(Ï„âˆ’1)âˆ¥+Î·â€‹Î”n,Ï„lâˆ£Ï„âˆ’1âˆ¥ğ’–n(Ï„âˆ’1)âˆ’ğ’—(Ï„âˆ’1)âˆ¥+Î·â€‹Î²â€‹âˆ‘mâˆˆâ„°nÎ±m,nâ€‹âˆ¥ğ’˜m(Ï„âˆ’1)âˆ’ğ’—(Ï„âˆ’1)âˆ¥+Î·â€‹Î”n,Ï„lâˆ¤Ï„âˆ’1.cases1ğœ‚ğ›½delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscriptğ’–ğ‘›ğœ1superscriptğ’—ğœ1ğœ‚subscriptÎ”ğ‘›conditionalsubscriptğœğ‘™ğœ1otherwisedelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscriptğ’–ğ‘›ğœ1superscriptğ’—ğœ1otherwisenot-dividesğœ‚ğ›½subscriptğ‘šsubscriptâ„°ğ‘›subscriptğ›¼ğ‘šğ‘›delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘šğœ1superscriptğ’—ğœ1ğœ‚subscriptÎ”ğ‘›subscriptğœğ‘™ğœ1otherwise\displaystyle\begin{cases}\left(1+\eta\beta\right)\left\lVert{\boldsymbol{u}_{n}^{(\tau-1)}-\boldsymbol{v}^{(\tau-1)}}\right\rVert+\eta\Delta_{n},\tau_{l}\mid\tau-1\\ \left\lVert{\boldsymbol{u}_{n}^{(\tau-1)}-\boldsymbol{v}^{(\tau-1)}}\right\rVert\\ +\eta\beta\sum\limits_{m\in\mathcal{E}_{n}}\alpha_{m,n}\left\lVert{\boldsymbol{w}_{m}^{(\tau-1)}-\boldsymbol{v}^{(\tau-1)}}\right\rVert+\eta\Delta_{n},\tau_{l}\nmid\tau-1.\end{cases} (79)
